channel.title: Addressing Climate Change in the Water Sector
channel.description: Updated Addressing Climate Change in the Water Sector content from the US Environmental Protection Agency

item.title: National Action Plan: Priorities for Managing Freshwater Resources in a Changing Climate
item.description:
The National Action Plan is based on the latest science on climate risks to freshwater resources. The Plan establishes a national goal to have government agencies and citizens collaboratively manage freshwater resources in response to a changing climate. This plan aims to ensure adequate water supplies, to safeguard human life, health and property, and to protect water quality and aquatic ecosystems. 

  • National Action Plan: Priorities for Managing Freshwater Resources in a Changing Climate (PDF)(76 pp, 29 MB)
item.dc:creator: inasir

item.title: Directory of Regional Climate Change Adaptation Programs of Federal Natural Resources Agencies
item.description:
This directory was developed as a tool to strengthen coordination between regional programs of federal natural resource agencies to assist in preparing for a changing climate. It may also serve to help States, Tribes, local governments, and other stakeholders be informed of federal agency resources that are deployed on a regional basis to build climate resilience.

(If you have difficulty accessing this PDF document, please email water_climate_change@epa.gov for assistance.)

  • Directory of Regional Climate Change Adaptation Programs of Federal Natural Resources Agencies (PDF)(39 pp, 1 MB)
item.dc:creator: egoldste

item.title: State Water Agency Practices for Climate Adaptation Database
item.description:
The compilation of practices featured below highlight some of the innovative actions or planning efforts by various state water management agencies that help address a changing climate. Showcasing a diverse array of climate adaptation related practices in several programmatic areas and geographic locations around the country can help encourage the adoption of useful models across state agencies.

January 3, 2017 - We are pleased to announce that a second round of practices has been added to the compilation below.

If you would like to submit a climate related practice from your state agency for consideration, please contact water_climate_change@epa.gov for more details.

To download the documents, scroll to the bottom of the page.

State Title of State Practice Topic Area
AZ Ensuring Water Supply Sustainability: Arizona Department of Water Resources' Drought and Water Supply Planning Drinking Water, Water Supply Planning, Water Conservation, Drought
AZ Arizona Uses Water Infrastructure Finance Authority to Provide Funding for Infrastructure Projects that Address Climate Impacts Water Supply Planning, Water Conservation, Resource Efficiency, Green Infrastructure, Funding 
CA California Integrated Assessment of Watershed Health  Monitoring and Assessment
CA California “Save Our Water” Conservation Education Program Water Conservation
CO Using Colorado WaterWise to Achieve Water Efficiency in a Changing Climate Water Conservation
CO Planning for Impacts of Climate Change on Colorado’s Water Supply Water Supply Planning, Water Conservation, Drought, Modeling/Research 
IL Planning for Climate Variability: Illinois State Water Survey and Statewide Framework for Drought and Water Supply Planning Water Supply Planning
MA Maintaining Integrity of River and Stream Ecosystems with Massachusetts River and Stream Continuity Partnership Ecosystem Connectivity, Monitoring and Assessment 
MD Conserving Maryland’s Wetlands in a Changing Climate using Sea Level Affecting Marshes Model Wetlands 
MD Maryland Supplements Long Term Water Supply Planning Requirements with “Message on Climate Change” Water Supply Planning
MN Promoting Climate Change Adaptation through Minnesota’s Stormwater Manual and Design Standards Green Infrastructure/ Stormwater
MN Long-term Monitoring to Help Detect Climate Variability in Minnesota Monitoring and Assessment, Wetlands, Modeling/Research, Water Quality Standards
NH New Hampshire Considers Climate Change in Wetlands Program Plan and Review Process Wetlands 
NH New Hampshire Drinking Water Program’s Climate Change Resilience Plan Water Supply Planning, Drinking Water, Water Quality Standards
NM Wetland Protection and Beaver Habitat Restoration as Climate Adaptation Tools in New Mexico Wetlands, Monitoring, and Assessment
OR Oregon Builds Ecosystem Resilience to Climate Change with Thermal Refugia and Temperature Standard Water Quality Standards, National Polluntant Discharge Elimination System, Total Maximum Daily Loads
OR Oregon’s Strategy to Build Capacity and Address Harmful Algal Blooms in a Changing Climate Drinking Water, Monitoring and Assessment, National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System, Total Maximum Daily Loads, Water Quality Standards
WA Washington’s Integrated Plan to Create Partnerships and Diversify Funding for Climate Adaptation Water Supply Planning, Water Conservation, Integrated Water Resource Management 

  • Ensuring Water Supply Sustainability: Arizona Department of Water Resources’ Drought and Water Supply Planning (PDF)(3 pp, 881 K)
  • Arizona Uses the Water Infrastructure Finance Authority to Provide Funding for Infrastructure Projects that Address Climate Impacts (PDF)(2 pp, 714 K)
  • California Integrated Assessment of Watershed Health (PDF)(2 pp, 792 K)
  • California “Save Our Water” Conservation Education Program (PDF)(2 pp, 694 K)

  • Minnesota’s Stormwater Manual and Design Standards Address Climate Change Adaptation (PDF)(2 pp, 642 K, 10.16.15)

item.dc:creator: egoldste

item.title: State Water Agency Practices for Climate Adaptation
item.description:
January 3, 2017 - We are pleased to announce that a second round of practices have been released. Click on the button (in orange) below.

State water agencies across the country are starting to integrate climate change considerations into the Clean Water Act and Safe Drinking Water Act programs they administer.

Short descriptions have been developed of innovative practices that state water agencies are currently implementing to reduce their vulnerability to climate-related impacts and to build resilience to climate change. These select state practices can serve as useful models for other state agencies seeking to make water programs more resilient to climate change. In addition, water resource planners and decision-makers from local and tribal governments and other entities may find these practices  helpful.  

The practices described are the result of a collaborative effort by the Association of Clean Water Administrators (ACWA), Association of State Drinking Water Administrators (ASDWA), Association of State Wetland Managers (ASWM), and the EPA Office of Water to:

  1. Identify select practices that state water agencies are currently implementing in response to climate variability,
  2. Select practices from diverse water program areas and geographic locations around the country; and 
  3. Work with state programs to compose descriptions that could be useful to other state agencies.

If you would like to propose a climate related practice from your state agency for consideration, email water_climate_change@epa.gov with the details.

  • Learn more about ACWA, ASWM, and ASDWA
  • Additional Resources and Tools
item.dc:creator: egoldste

item.title: Planning and Management: Programmatic Response to Climate Change and Water
item.description:
Below are descriptions of documents developed by the EPA National Water Program, detailing programmatic efforts to address climate change impacts to water resources. To download the documents, scroll to the bottom of the page. 
 
2016 Highlights of Progress Report Released

2016 Workplan: EPA National Water Program Response to Climate Change
The Workplan lays out the actions that the EPA National Water Program plans to take in 2016 to implement the “EPA National Water Program 2012 Strategy: Response to Climate Change." It is intended to be a roadmap to guide program planning and inform decision-makers during the Agency’s planning and budgeting process. The 2016 Workplan builds on work conducted in 2012-2014. View and download the document.
 

2015 Workplan: EPA National Water Program Response to Climate Change 
The Workplan lays out the actions that the EPA National Water Program planned to take in 2015. 
View and download the document.


 

EPA Office of Water Climate Change Adaptation Implementation Plan (2014)
The Implementation Plan provides an overview of the opportunities available to the Office of Water within the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency to respond climate challenges.  The Plan addresses specific challenges for the operation of national programs to protect the water quality and drinking water in a changing climate. 
View and download the document.

EPA National Water Program 2012 Strategy: Response to Climate Change 
The Strategy sets out EPA's long-term goals and specific actions to prepare for and build resilience to the impacts of a changing climate on water resources. The Strategy is organized around five programmatic vision areas: protecting water infrastructure; coastal and ocean waters; watersheds; water quality, and working with Tribes. View and download the document.
 
To order copies of the EPA National Water Program 2012 Strategy: Response to Climate Change, visit: http://www.epa.gov/nscep/ordering. Ordering can be done online, by phone, or by mail. The document number is: 850-K-12-004.
 
The following Highlights of Progress Reports provide a summary of the major climate change-related accomplishments of EPA's national and regional water programs. The reports reflect annual implementation of the EPA National Water Program 2012 Strategy: Response to Climate Change.
 
2016 Highlights of Progress: Reponses to Climate Change by the EPA National Water Program 
View and download the document. 


 

2015 Highlights of Progress: Responses to Climate Change by the EPA National Water Program 
View and download the document. 
 
 

 

2014 Highlights of Progress: Responses to Climate Change by the EPA National Water Program
View and download the document.

 

 
2013 Highlights of Progress: Responses to Climate Change by the EPA National Water Program
View and download the document.



 
 
2012 Highlights of Progress: Responses to Climate Change by the EPA National Water Program
View and download the document.


 
 

Document Links:

item.title: Climate Change and Water News
item.description:
​EPA Climate Change and Water News features news and information from EPA and other federal agencies related to climate change and water. Partner activities, as well as related events and publications, are also included. The newsletter is sent out approximately every two weeks to subscribers. Issues from the past three months are available below.

EPA Climate Change and Water News

          Click here to sign up!





 

  • To submit an item for EPA Climate Change and Water News, provide feedback, or contact us with questions:
    Send an email to water_climate_change@epa.gov.

item.dc:creator: inasir

item.title: Federal Collaborations Addressing Climate Change and Water
item.description:
Executive InitiativesYou will need Adobe Reader to view some of the files on this page. See EPA’s About PDF page to learn more.
  • Looking Forward: Priorities for Managing Freshwater Resources in a Changing Climate
  • National Action Plan: Priorities for Managing Freshwater Resources in a Changing Climate
  • National Fish Wildlife and Plants Climate Adaptation Strategy
Other Federal Collaborations
  • Advisory Committee on Water Information (ACWI) - Water Resources Adaptation to Climate Change Workgroup
  • Climate Change and Water Working Group (CCAWG)
  • National Integrated Drought Information System (NIDIS)

  • U.S. Global Change Research Program

Resources

  • Directory of Regional Climate Change Adaptation Programs of Federal Natural Resources Agencies

The following links exit the site Exit

Executive Initiatives

Looking Forward: Priorities for Managing Freshwater Resources in a Changing Climate
This report addresses ways to build resilience to climate change for water resources. It updates a 2011 National Action Plan which outlines priority actions to make progress in three key areas: data and research, planning and decision support, and training and outreach. Fourteen federal agencies were involved in developing this report and are undertaking efforts to build the nation’s preparedness to extreme events. 

National Action Plan: Priorities for Managing Freshwater Resources in a Changing Climate

The National Action Plan is based on the latest science on climate risks to freshwater resources. The Plan establishes a national goal to have government agencies and citizens collaboratively manage freshwater resources in response to a changing climate. This plan aims to ensure adequate water supplies, to safeguard human life, health and property, and to protect water quality and aquatic ecosystems. 

National Fish Wildlife and Plants Climate Adaptation Strategy
In response to increasing impacts of climate change and other stressors on America’s natural resources, the United States Congress called for action. The resulting national strategy aims to safeguard fish, wildlife, plants, and the natural systems upon which they depend. The Strategy was developed with input from a broad range of federal, state, and tribal partners.
 

Top of Page

Other Federal Collaborations

Advisory Committee on Water Information (ACWI) - Water Resources Adaptation to Climate Change Workgroup
ACWI represents the interests of water information users and professionals in advising the federal government on water-information programs and their effectiveness in meeting the Nation's needs. The Climate Change Workgroup identifies research, data, and policy necessary for effective management and protection of water resources in the United States.
 
Climate Change and Water Working Group (CCAWG)
The federal Climate Change and Water Working Group (CCAWWG) provides engineering and scientific collaborations in support of water management under a changing climate. It is an effective working-level forum among federal agencies that fosters communication, operational, and research partnerships around user needs across the water and science communities
 
National Integrated Drought Information System (NIDIS)

The National Integrated Drought Information System (NIDIS), headed by NOAA, conducts workshops and meetings with federal, state and local agencies, academic researchers, and other stakeholders. Resources, regional programs, and tools are found on this website. 

U.S. Global Change Research Program
The U.S. Global Change Research Program (USGCRP) was established by Presidential Initiative in 1989 and mandated by Congress in the Global Change Research Act of 1990. The Program aims to "assist the Nation and the world to understand, assess, predict, and respond to human-induced and natural processes of global change.” The National Climate Assessment, a significant USGCRP product, summarizes the impacts of climate change on the United States, now and in the future.

Top of Page
item.dc:creator: inasir

item.title: Regional Actions to Address Climate Change Impacts on Water
item.description:
Click on a region below to jump to information specific to that region.You will need Adobe Reader to view some of the files on this page. See EPA’s About PDF page to learn more.

EPA Region 1

Climate Change Impacts on Water Resources and Regional Actions to Address Them  
  • To learn more about climate impacts in the region, visit EPA's "Climate Impacts in the Northeast" page.
  • More information on the impacts of a changing climate on water in Region 1 can be found in the National Climate Assessment Northeast chapter. Exit   
  • EPA Region 1 Climate Change Adaptation Implementation Plan (PDF)

EPA Region 2

Climate Change Impacts on Water Resources and Regional Actions to Address Them  
EPA Region 2 includes areas both in the Northeast as well as the
Caribbean. Climate change information can be found for both regions below.
  • To learn more about climate impacts in the region, visit EPA's "Climate Impacts in the Northeast" and “Climate Impacts in U.S. Islands” page.
  • More information on the impacts of a changing climate on water in Region 2 can be found in the National Climate Assessment Northeast chapter Exit as well as the Southeast and Caribbean chapter. Exit

EPA Region 6

Climate Change Impacts on Water Resources and Regional Actions to Address Them
EPA Region 6 includes areas in the Southwest, Great Plains, as well as the
Southeast. Climate change information can be found for those three regions below.  
  • To learn more about climate impacts in the region, visit EPA’s “Climate Impacts in the Southwest,”  “Climate Impacts in the Great Plains," and “Climate Impacts in the Southeast,”  pages.
  • More information on the impacts of a changing climate on water in Region 6 can be found in the National Climate Assessment Southwest chapter Exit, National Climate Assessment Great Plains chapter Exit, and National Climate Assessment Southeast chapter. Exit 
  • EPA Region 6 Climate Change Adaptation Implementation Plan (PDF)
Region 6 Water Program Climate Partnerships: The following links exit the site Exit
  • Landscape Conservation Cooperatives: Great Plains; Southern Rockies; Desert; Gulf Coast Prarie; and Gulf Coastal Plains and Ozarks
  • Climate Science Centers: South Central and Southeast
  • USDA Climate Hubs: Southwest; Southern Plains; and Southeast
Top of Page

EPA Region 7

Climate Change Impacts on Water Resources and Regional Actions to Address Them
EPA Region 7 includes areas both in the Great Plains as well as the
Midwest. Climate change information can be found for both regions below.  
  • To learn more about climate impacts in the region, visit EPA’s “Climate Impacts in the Great Plains" and “Climate Impacts in the Midwest”  pages.
  • More information on the impacts of a changing climate on water in Region 7 can be found in the National Climate Assessment  Great Plains chapter Exit and National Climate Assessment  Midwest chapter. Exit 
  • EPA Region 7 Climate Change Adaptation Implementation Plan (PDF)
Region 7 Water Program Climate Partnerships: The following links exit the site Exit
  • Landscape Conservation Cooperatives: Plains and Prairie Potholes and Great Northern 
  • Climate Science Centers: Northeast,  North Central, and Southeast
  • USDA Northern Plains Climate Hub
Top of Page

EPA Region 8

Climate Change Impacts on Water Resources and Regional Actions to Address Them  
EPA Region 8 includes areas both in the Great Plains as well as the
Southwest. Climate change information can be found for both regions below. 
  • To learn more about climate impacts in the region, visit EPA’s “Climate Impacts in the Great Plains" and “Climate Impacts in the Southwest” pages.
  • More information on the impacts of a changing climate on water in Region 8 can be found in the National Climate Assessment Great Plains chapter Exit and National Climate Assessment Southwest chapter. Exit
  • EPA Region 8 Climate Change Adaptation Implementation Plan (PDF)
Region 8 Water Program Climate Partnerships: The following links exit the site Exit
  • Landscape Conservation Cooperatives: Great Northern; Great Basin; Southern Rockies; Great Plains; and Plains and Prarie Potholes
  • Climate Science Centers: Southwest and North Central

  • USDA Climate Hubs: Southwest and Northern Plains

Top of Page

EPA Region 9

Climate Change Impacts on Water Resources and Regional Actions to Address Them 
  • To learn more about climate impacts in the region, visit EPA’s “Climate Impacts in the Southwest” page.
  • More information on the impacts of a changing climate on water in Region 8 can be found in the National Climate Assessment Southwest chapter. Exit
  • EPA Region 9 Climate Change Adaptation Implementation Plan (PDF)

EPA Region 10

  • To learn more about climate impacts in the region, visit EPA’s “Climate Impacts in the Northwest” page.

item.dc:creator: egoldste

item.title: EPA Programs and Initiatives Addressing Climate Change in the Water Sector
item.description:
Water Infrastructure Programs and Initiatives
  • Climate Ready Water Utilities (CRWU)
  • Effective and Sustainable Water Utility Management
  • Emergency Response for Drinking Water and Wastewater Utilities
  • Green Infrastructure and Low Impact Development
  • Sustainable Infrastructure
  • WaterSense
Other Water Programs and Initiatives
  • Climate Ready Estuaries (CRE)
  • Healthy Watersheds
  • Water Quality Models and Tools

Water Infrastructure Programs and Initiatives

Climate Ready Water Utilities (CRWU)
EPA's Climate Ready Water Utilities (CRWU) initiative is aimed at preparing the water sector, including drinking water, wastewater, and stormwater utilities, for climate change impacts. Extreme weather events, sea level rise, shifting precipitation patterns, and temperature variability, all intensified by climate change, have significant impacts for such utilities. Through the development of easy-to-use tools (including CREAT), this program promotes a clear understanding of how utilities can adapt to climate change.

Watch how several community drinking water and wastewater utilities are responding to extreme events and planning for their climate futures:
Fredricktown, Missouri
Camden, New Jersey
Harrisburg, Pennsylvania
Manchester-by-the-Sea, Massachusetts
Faribault, Minnesota

Effective and Sustainable Water Utility Management
EPA is working collaboratively with six national organizations that support drinking water and wastewater utilities to promote effective utility management. Attributes of effectively managed water sector utilities were identified by a group of leading water sector utility managers from across the nation. The goal of the Effective Utility Management Initiative is to help utilities address a full range of challenges to move toward sustainable operations and infrastructure.

Emergency Response for Drinking Water and Wastewater Utilities
EPA has developed a variety of guidance documents and other informative resources to support drinking water and wastewater preparedness, response and recovery. The tools and resources available on this site include the new “Flood Resilience: A Basic Guide for Water and Wastewater Utilities.” The Guide helps utilities prepare for the extreme weather events associated with climate change.

Green Infrastructure and Low Impact Development (LID)
The Green Infrastructure site provides tools, case studies, research, and other information to help users learn more about green infrastructure. Green Infrastructure uses natural hydrologic features to manage water and provide environmental and community benefits, including climate change resilience.

The second site focuses on Low Impact Development, which aims to manage stormwater close to the source and includes “green infrastructure” techniques. This website provides fact sheets, reports, videos, and informational resources about low impact development.

Sustainable Infrastructure
EPA is committed to promoting sustainable practices that will help ensure that citizens continue to enjoy the benefits of clean and safe water. Guided by the Agency's Clean Water and Drinking Water Infrastructure Sustainability Policy, EPA is working with stakeholders to help bring about more sustainable practices.

WaterSense
WaterSense is an EPA program that partners with a variety of stakeholders to promote water efficiency. WaterSense works with stakeholders to provide consumers with easy ways to save water through labeled products as well as information resources. WaterSense also encourages innovation in manufacturing to decrease water use and reduce strain on water resources and infrastructure.

Top of Page

Other Water Programs and Initiatives

Climate Ready Estuaries (CRE)
EPA's Climate Ready Estuaries (CRE) program works with the National Estuary Programs and the coastal management community. CRE helps these groups assess climate change vulnerabilities, develop and implement adaptation strategies, and engage and educate stakeholders. The program helps coastal managers and other place-based organizations by providing technical assistance by providing tools such as the "Being Prepared for Climate Change" workbook. 

Healthy Watersheds
EPA's Healthy Watersheds program proactively protects aquatic ecosystems through watershed protection. This systems approach protects aquatic biota and their habitat as well as watershed characteristics and processes that support them. Vegetative riparian corridors and headwaters, hydrology, geomorphology, and natural disturbance regimes are specific focus areas of this program. Healthy Watersheds also addresses pervasive threats to watersheds including climate change.

Water Quality Models and Tools
This website contains a variety of tools and models ideal for water utility and watershed professionals. Models and tools found here simulate the movement of precipitation and pollutants from the ground surface through pipe and channel networks, and to receiving waters. Both single-event and continuous simulation may be performed on catchments having storm sewers and natural drainage, for prediction of flows, stages, and pollutant concentrations.

Top of Page
item.dc:creator: egoldste
